newsitem.title: HONG KONG: PRESS DIGEST-Hong Kong Newspaper Headlines-Apr 28.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-Hong Kong Newspaper Headlines-Apr 28.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Hong Kong press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- MING PAO -- About 100,000 Hong Kong people witnessed a spectacular fireworks and laser display to mark the opening of the Tsing Ma Bridge. Former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Governor Chris Patten and Chief Secretary Anson Chan gave speeches at the ceremony.

-- ECONOMIC TIMES -- A senior Chinese official said Chinese companies overseas should get approval from securities regulators in China commission before seeking to list shares outside China. He also said that red-chip companies' investments in China should abide by investment regulations.

-- SING TAO -- Sources said that the death of veteran Chinese leader Peng Zhen would help strengthen President Jiang Zemin's position and would accelerate investigations into officials close to disgraced former Beijing leader Chen Xitong.
-- TA KUNG PAO -- The office of Hong Kong's future leader Tung Chee-Hwa is to take measures to regulate the immigration of mainland children.

-- SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST -- The World Bank said that China risked being left with a rump of inefficient, unwanted state-owned enterprises that threaten to burden the government if it failed to fully embrace economic reforms.
-- The United States' senior diplomat in Hong Kong expressed "serious concern" about proposed restrictions on street marches in the territory.

-- HONGKONG STANDARD -- Two people in China's northwestern Xinjiang region were killed after the trial of 30 ringleaders involved in riots in February triggered more bloodshed, a senior regional official said.
-- Chief Executive-designate Tung Chee-hwa called for Hong Kong's Kai Tak airport to be redeveloped as quickly as possible once the new Chek Lap Kok airport is completed.
